Findings yielded by the present study identify two groups of tactical sourcing levers, the first of which consists of volume bundling, price evaluation and extension of supply base.
In nearly all portfolio quadrants, these are the most frequently employed levers.
These represent what authors call the transaction-oriented, more traditional sourcing levers focused on capturing most of the value on the supply market in a rather adversarial approach.
The second group consists of product optimization, process optimization, optimization of supply relationships and category-spanned optimization.
In this study, these are the least used levers for nearly all portfolio quadrants.
According to the extant literature, these levers are intended to focus on creating value in the supply market via a relationship-oriented, more advanced approach.

In the analyzed sourcing projects, purchasing teams generally tend to apply transaction-oriented levers to all portfolio quadrants and selectively add more efforts to relationship-oriented levers, when strategic importance increases and supply risk reduces.
It is striking that the scores for most tactical sourcing levers are below the mid-point of the 7-point Likert scale with little deviation.
Only volume bundling and price evaluation just score above the mid-point for nearly all portfolio quadrants.
Overall, the data shows that the respondents opted for a wide range of sourcing levers without focusing on a few or single lever in extreme form.
Several of the present study findings are well aligned with the tactics recommended in pertinent literature.
For instance, price evaluation has been most applied to leverage and strategic purchases.
This corresponds to with earlier studies recommending target pricing for leverage purchases.
Open book costing for strategic purchases.

Similarly, in correspondence to existing studies calling for long-term, privileged relationships, optimization of supply relationships was most applied strategic and least applied for non-critical purchases.
Still, in many cases, empirical reality diverges from the conceptual, normative recommendations.

On the other hands, optimization of supply relationships is frequently used for bottleneck purchases, instead of the recommended extension of the supply base as a means of expanding the network of alternative sources.
For strategic purchases, volume bundling and price evaluation are even more employed than that the highly recommended optimization of supply relationships.
Moreover, several publications create the impression that most tactical sourcing levers are exclusively limited to a single portfolio quadrant.
For example, efficient processing is deemend applicable solely to non-critical purchases.
Long-term supply relationships pertain to strategic purchases only.

However, findings yielded by this study confirm that, although literature makes generic recommendations for a certain portfolio quadrant, this does not mean that the rest of the requirements does not apply in that quadrant.
They do, but it helps to understand the prime focus for each quadrant.
Thus, the present study is the first to provide survey-based empirical evidence supporting the conclusion that tactical sourcing levers are not exclusive to a specific portfolio quadrant.
Rather, the entire range of tactical sourcing levers is applied in practice to each portfolio quadrant.
In addition, purchasers tend to dedicate more effort to the process when moving from bottleneck to non-critical, to strategic and finally to leverage purchases.
Overall, the least effort was invested into bottleneck purchases.
For non-critical purchases, more effort was added, especially to extension of supply base, product optimization and price evaluation.
Efforts increased further for strategic purchases, in particular for optimization of supply relationships and volume bundling.
Ultimately, for leverage purchases, additional effort was invested into price evaluation and category-spanned optimization.
In sum, in practice, tactical sourcing levers are applied in an additive manner, rather as alternatives.
Caniels and Gelderman give a possible explanation for this phenomenon.
In their analysis, the buyer-supplier relationships for bottleneck purchases are supplier-dominated.
Leverage purchases are buyer-dominated.
A supplier-dominated power regime may lead to lock-in situations in which the buyers ability to enforce their goals and tactics is often very limited.
In contrast, buyer dominance increases the buyers influence and value appropriation.
Consequently, in the analyzed data set, buyers may have spent the least efforts on tactical sourcing levers for bottleneck purchases.
To date, in supply management, purchasing portfolio models have been widely adopted to cluster and strategically manage different types of purchases.
Although it still attracts criticism, the Kraljic matrix remains the dominant approach in purchasing portfolio management.
The traditional idea of the Kraljic matrix is intuitively appealing as purchases are grouped into four portfolio quadrants, namely non-critical, leverage, bottleneck and strategic purchases.
This classification is based on the strategic importance of each acquisition and the supply risk they impose for the buyer.
Purchasers follow tactical recommendations for each portfolio quadrant to maximize purchasing performance.
However, in practice, strategy implementation is not that straight forward, as it typically requires discussing and balancing a set tactics.
Tactical sourcing levers have an immediate practical relevance as they address the activities that purchasers use to achieve their goals.

Extant research on portfolio models contributed little to the effort to verify if, in practice, tactical sourcing levers are applied according to the specific, generic recommendations for each portfolio quadrant.
This study set out to rectify this omission.
Following a mixed methods approach, a survey instrument was developed based on a literature review and highly interactive world caf discussions.

Measurement scales were subsequently developed for the seven core tactical sourcing lever, comprising of volume bundling, price evaluation, extension of supply base, product optimization, process optimization, optimization of supply relationships and category-spanned optimization.
Thereafter, 107 direct sourcing projects were analyzed for their strategic importance, supply risk and sourcing lever profile.
The sourcing projects were thus classified into non-critical, leverage, bottleneck and strategic purchases.
Finally, these groups of sourcing projects were tested with respect to differences and similarities in the application of the seven core tactical sourcing levers.
The findings of this study call for a more differentiated view on recommendations by portfolio models, as was already suggested a decade ago.
The study confirms that tactical sourcing levers are not applied as alternatives.
Rather, a mix of the entire range of tactical sourcing levers is utilized with respect to each portfolio quadrant and more effort is added when moving from bottleneck to leverage purchases.
Previous studies on portfolio models have tended to focus on overall strategic recommendations for each portfolio quadrant.
Thereby, they have contrasted portfolio quadrants in terms of differences in product characteristics, purchasing skills, buyer-supplier relationships, power structures and organizational structures.
This study goes beyond the approach adopted in these works, as it empirically links specific, actionable tactical sourcing levers to purchasing portfolio theory.
The study presents several contributions.

First, as initially intended by Kraljic's policy issues, the present study confirms that purchasing portfolio theory can play an important role in choosing and configuring a set of tactics to improve purchasing performance.
Its findings show that purchasers clearly apply a differentiated profile of tactical sourcing levers to each portfolio quadrant.

By operationalizing the seven discussed core tactical sourcing levers, this study provides 23 activities that can be applied in practice as a checklist to identify improvement potentials or each sourcing project.
This activity level of analysis may provide a rich line of inquiry for future studies.
It may for example be interesting to analyze in more details why some of the activities from each tactical sourcing lever did or did not vary between the portfolio quadrants, as potentially expected.
Second, the study provides evidence that purchasers differentiate between two groups of tactical sourcing levers.
More specifically, volume bundling, price evaluation and extension of supply base are mainly transaction-oriented and focus on capturing existing value.
These levers have been applied most frequently in the sample analyzed in this study, irrespective of the portfolio quadrant.

On the other hand, product optimization, process optimization, optimization of supply relationships and category-spanned optimization are predominately relationship-oriented and focus on creating value in collaboration with various actors.
These levers require collaboration across multiple functions.
However, they have been used the least across all portfolio quadrants.
For several years, many scholars assumed superiority of relationship-orientation over transaction-orientation in purchasing.
However, this study yielded the contrary findings.

Hence, it might be fruitful to further examine at the tactical level why purchasers invest greater effort into transaction-oriented than into relationship-oriented approaches, as well as whether trade-offs exist between these approaches.
In the analyzed sample, purchasing teams did not limit certain tactical sourcing levers exclusively to a single portfolio quadrant.
Each of the seven core tactical sourcing levers was applied to all portfolio quadrants.

This confirms earlier critique on a deterministic adoption and implementation of the generic recommendations for each portfolio quadrant, such as forming cooperative partnerships for all strategic purchases.
Yet, the full range of tactical sourcing levers may be used in each of the four quadrants.

This finding has important implications on the way portfolio models are used: The generic recommendations made by purchasing portfolio models and other management tools may serve as spaces for debate and social interaction but will most probably not provide the definite answer to strategic or tactical problems.

Purchasing portfolio models may especially be useful in the discussion about general purchasing approaches at a more abstract, general level with personnel from other functions which are not directly involved with purchasing activities.

However, in the implementation, purchasing professionals may still opt for the tactics that best fit the supply market conditions of the sourcing category at hand, even if they are not among the generic recommendations.
Future research might ask whether a strict, deterministic adherence to generic recommendation may even reduce purchasing performance.
Fourth, in the analyzed sample, more effort to implement tactical sourcing levers was added when moving from bottleneck, to non-critical, to strategic and finally to leverage purchases.
In other words, purchasing teams clearly concentrated their activities on leverage and strategic purchases and exerted less activities on non-critical and bottleneck purchases.
This suggests that the application of tactical sourcing levers within the Kraljic matrix is done in an additive manner.

This additive pattern suggests that purchasers draw the attention to particularly important and critical purchases to limit the extent of necessary analyses and data, which might in fact be a meaningful pattern of time and resource allocation.
A possible explanation may be that purchasers adapted their effort to the portfolio quadrant-specific power structures and resulting prospects of success.
Bottleneck purchases are often supplier-dominated and may thus be less favorable for the purchasers to reach their goals.
Tthe buyer-dominated leverage purchases.
Previous findings suggest that a purchasing portfolio analysis should play a major role in determining resources and involvement of purchasing teams.
Future studies might address this point to better understand how a sourcing team's resource availability influences performance outcomes in each of the four portfolio quadrants.
Do more resources in each quadrant lead to more success or should these resources mainly be bundled on the important and critical purchases as Kraljic suggests?

In conclusion, findings yielded by this study confirm that the logic of the deterministic, generic recommendations made in the quadrants of the Kraljic matrix are not coherent, are sometimes misguided and often lead to the cherry-picking of sourcing levers from other quadrants.

In the light of the on-going debate about the rigor and robustness of the Kraljic matrix, future research and practice may build on a finer differentiated approach to purchasing category management as discussed by the concept of category supply management, power positioning tools, category management in purchasing or the concept of modern category management.

To account better for the peculiarities of each material or service group, organizations may move away from a limited number of four or nine portfolio cells towards a finer differentiation of sourcing categories.

In a modern category management approach, a firm may distinguish several hundreds of sourcing categories, such as metal sheets, battery systems or leather applications, based on differentiators such as production technology, supplier competences or market-facing areas.

Ultimately, instead of following generic, norm strategies and tactics for all materials or services placed in the same portfolio quadrant, category managers might follow an individual strategy for each sourcing category, even when placed in the same portfolio area.

Purchasing portfolio models and their generic recommendations may still play an important role to cluster a firm's or department's range of sourcing categories and serve as a platform for a fruitful discussion about possible purchasing approaches among the involved stakeholders.
However, these generic recommendations will most likely not provide a definite answer.

A finer differentiated market understanding of modern category management with potentially hundreds of individual sourcing category strategies, may require entirely new predictive tools that help the front-line purchasers in choosing which activities are more or less appropriate in particular circumstances.

A major strength of this study lies in the research design which relies on the experience of front-line purchasing agents, most knowledgeable about the sourcing context and tactical sourcing levers they have to consider in their daily work.
The study intentionally focused on direct sourcing projects sourced within a timeframe of 6 month within one large, global automotive OEM to allow for intense academic-practitioner collaboration.
Moreover, this focus also facilitated access to the knowledge of a comparable and reasonably large group of purchasing agents within a consistent organizational context.
The automotive industry generally includes a large variety of purchased items.
Still, the study is unlikely to provide general guidelines for other industries, and especially for the service or the public sector.

Further data collection in other industries and the public sector, including indirect purchases and a different time period for additional testing of the proposed patterns in tactical sourcing lever application, is desirable.
Strategic importance and supply risk and thus the positioning of products in the Kraljic matrix may change over time.
Therefore, this study intentionally focused on sourcing levers profiles within a limited time frame to allow a classification of the respective sourcing projects into the Kraljic matrix.

Purchasing strategies are a significant contributing factor to the overall performance of a firm.

Not only has it been argued that transitioning purchasing from a tactical to a strategic role provides sustainable competitive advantage, compelling evidence supports the relationship between strategic purchasing and supplier integration, performance, power, and total cost of ownership among other benefits.
Consequently, it has become widely accepted that establishing a strategic purchasing approach is imperative for today's firm.
Towards this goal, employing a purchasing portfolio approach has become prevalent in both academia and within organizations to improve strategic purchasing.
The most established portfolio model in literature and practice is Kraljic's model known as the Kraljic Portfolio Matrix.

The KPM employs a matrix comprised of four portfolio quadrants to categorize purchases according to a range of internal, product, profit and operational factors along with external, supply market conditions.

The general idea behind the KPM is to minimize supply vulnerability and maximize buying power while at the same time matching external resources provided by suppliers with the internal needs of the buying firm.

Moreover, the KPM has been found to provide additional benefits such as improving internal cross-functional coordination, visualizing and illustrating the purchasing strategy, and diversifying supplier power dependencies.
Thus, the KPM approach has been argued to represent the single most diagnostic and prescriptive tool available to purchasing organizations.
However, the Kraljic model is not without its critics.
One of the primary weaknesses of the KPM is the qualitative nature of the model, which results in a subjective method for weighting and positioning suppliers or commodities in the quadrants.

In fact, Olsen and Ellram emphasized that the weighting of each factor, which helps to determine the positioning, is the most important part of the implementation process, but at the same time is one of the most subjective elements of the KPM model and decision-makers must come to an agreement on these inputs.
To address this Padhi argue for less subjective methods for positioning purchases on the matrix.
However, advancements with this concern have been slow.

Other concerns with the KPM exist such as weakness in the measurement of dimensions and variables, lack of prescriptive suggestions for proactively changing the existing power dependence, disregard for the supplier side, and the failure to account for interdependencies between products and between agent relationships.

Nevertheless, even among these critics, there is wide consensus that the KPM model provides a useful tool for describing and differentiating purchasing situations and developing appropriate sourcing strategies.
The purpose of this paper is to address some of these concerns.
We propose the use of decision analysis to provide a systematic quantitative approach to making better decisions.
By incorporating decision analysis, we advance the KPM model to become more objective in nature.

Specifically, we propose the use of multi-objective decision analysis as a quantitative framework to objectively position purchases in the KPM matrix along with identifying which products and services to begin strategic sourcing efforts with.
We demonstrate our approach by positioning major products and services procured by an organization which sources over $10 billion per year for products and services across 79 locations.
Consequently, this paper contributes to the literature in two ways.
Providing a novel approach to objectively and quantitatively position products and services within the KPM.
Providing decision makers an approach to identify those products and services that are optimal candidates to begin strategic sourcing initiatives.
The outline of this paper follows.
First, we provide a succinct overview of purchasing portfolio models and the current gap in the literature for quantitatively positioning items within the KPM.
We then outline our proposed methodology along with the use-case application of our approach to a subset of the organization's products and services.
We then discuss the results and insights garnered from our analysis and end the paper with a short discussion of recommendations, future work and concluding statements.
Modern portfolio theory dates back to 1952 when Markowitz introduced a framework for assembling a portfolio of assets to balance expected return for a given level of risk.
The concept of portfolio models subsequently diffused into the strategic management, marketing, and production literature followed by the purchasing domain.
Purchasing portfolio models provide an approach for differentiating suppliers and commodities.
Purchasing portfolio models have received considerable attention from academia and within organizations.
This attention is driven by the recognition that the ability of the firm to manage supplier relations has been empirically linked to obtaining and sustaining a competitive advantage.
Moreover, suppliers have played an increasingly significant role in the success of firm.

However, all suppliers cannot be dealt with in the same way and the literature supports the need to differentiate supplier relationships through differentiation schemes offered by purchasing portfolio models.
Kraljic introduced the first comprehensive portfolio approach for purchasing and supply management.
Although other models have been developed, Kraljic's approach has become the dominant methodology built upon in literature and the foundation for purchasing strategies for many organizations.

Kraljic's approach leverages a portfolio matrix that classifies products on the basis of two dimensions: the external dimension concerns the factors regarding suppliers and supply market, while the internal dimension relates to the importance and value impact of a given product.
Each dimension needs to be assessed against a number of variables where an overall classification score is established.
The result is a matrix and a classification in four categories.

Leverage.
Bottleneck.
Strategic items as illustrated.
This categorization allows commodities to be classified in a way that minimizes the supply risk while maximizing purchasing power and value to the firm.
There are several variants to the KPM.
However, most alternatives build on and extend the KPM by focusing on the factors and variables to be measured.

Positioning commodities in this matrix form not only enables managers to visually see trade-offs between items, but the classification also allows firms to develop distinctive management approaches for each category.
In fact, they identified three generalized supplier strategies to associate with the purchasing strength versus supply market strength power positions.
Exploit: leverage buying power, whether through aggressive or collaborative means.
Balance: implement neither aggressive nor conservative purchasing approach.
Diversify: search for new suppliers or substitutes.
In addition to the variations in what determines the positioning of products, the KPM has also been used to shift products within the matrix.
For example, they illustrated how practitioners have used the matrix to encourage new market entrants, which moves an item to leverage status, and to set goals for sourcing improvements.
The simplicity and flexibility of the KPM design has been a significant contributing factor to its popularity.
Moreover, empirical studies have corroborated the usefulness and validity of KPM and purchasing portfolio analysis in practice.
Caniels and Gelderman assessed the credibility of the KPM and the factors applied to measure supply risk and value impact.
Leveraging data from Dutch purchasing professionals, they found theoretical and real situations that largely satisfy the purchasing strategies while assigning different commodities to the KPM.
Wagner and Johnson used interview and archival data for multinational companies and found a strong relationship between the portfolio approach and competitive advantages obtained.
Bensaou and Lilliecreutz and Ydreskog found that firms benefit from entering into a variety of relationships with different suppliers as directed by a KPM porfolio approach.
Ipso facto, purchasing porfolio analysis has been found to be one of the top purchasing and supply tools used in industry, second only to vendor rating.
However, one of the KPM's main critiques revolves around the question.
How does a purchasing manager position a product or service within the matrix?

Most of the research regarding the KPM involves the framework itself, movement within the framework, application of the framework to industry, strategies for the matrix categories, and buyer-supplier relationships that underpin management decisions prior to or after placement.

In fact, Padhi, state that positioning commodities in the KPM suggested in the literature are mainly based on subjective judgment of the decision makers to position the commodities in the different quadrants.
They lack analytical rigor, where subjective positioning of commodities may lead to erroneous outcomes.
Wagner and Johnson add that despite the abundance of research on relationship patterns and their impact on company performance, the how-to question has been widely neglected.
Ramsay identifies an absence of a conceptual framework to facilitate an analytical approach.
Padhi add that positioning of the items in the portfolio matrix by the purchasing managers are subjective and makes the portfolio models imprecise.
Knight reiterate the lack of analytical rigor, the difficulty in measuring the matrix dimensions, and the argument for less subjective methods for positioning purchases on the matrix.
Lee and Drake argue that lack of the synthesizing of qualitative and quantitative measures promote arbitrary classification of purchases.

Olsen and Ellram emphasize that categorizing of purchases in a portfolio model is very subjective, and perhaps the most important part of the implementation process and urge the use of quantitative methodologies.
Although not exhaustive, a review of literature identified only five attempts to use quantitative techniques to position items with the KPM.
Three of the five techniques rely on the concept of importance weights or importance scoring.
A review of the decision analysis literature reveals there may be a better approach.
The problem with importance weights is that they may not take into account the range between the least- and most-preferred options on each attribute.
Rather, swing weighting has become a common approach to more accurately capture the importance trade-space of given attributes.
There is a unique difference between importance weighting and swing weighting.
Importance weights are used to reflect the general importance of one attribute over another without regard to the difference between the worst and the best value points of each attribute.

Watson and Buede further state that when this difference from worst to best is not explicitly referenced in assessing weights, we obtain some general notion of importance, which is subject to great variation and argument among decision-makers.

Dillon-Merrill argue that importance weights do not take into account the range between the lowest and the highest levels of the value measures resulting in the potential for important measures to not be important to the decision.

Keeney adds that when we quantify objectives by simply asking for their relative importance, considerable misinformation about values is produced and a substantial opportunity to understand values is lost.
However, the use of swing weighting ensures we capture the full value preference structure rather than simply an arbitrary score or at best a hierarchy of importance.
Swing weighting also protects against the potential for loss of information, misunderstanding of decision-maker belief, and even loss of trade-offs between values.
Zhenfeng apply factor analysis techniques to the dimensions of the KPM.
However, the model lacks sufficient detail in derivation of variable scoring and positioning of items.
In all, the ability to extend this model for practical use is limited and its ease of implementation is inadequate.
The remaining quantitative method used to position items with the KPM is the Analytical Hierarchy Process.
This approach is not without its flaws.

From a general methodological viewpoint concerning AHP, Watson and Buede argue that although definitions for levels of importance are articulated, inconsistencies between importance pairings are common and additional methods must be used to resolve differences.
They add that instead of getting a decision-maker to wrestle with his values, the AHP tells him what they ought to be.

They further highlight that AHP fails to provide clarity between attributes by using a somewhat arbitrary representation of words by numbers which may be implying an underlying judgment structure which the decision-maker is unaware of and may disagree with.

Dyer remarks that the AHP, as it is traditionally applied to the evaluation of alternatives, generates rank orderings that are not meaningful with respect to the underlying preferences of the decision maker.
Kirkwood adds that the approach seems overly complex with its need for sometimes extensive pairwise comparisons of alternatives and extensive mathematical calculations to determine rankings.
These characteristics seem to obscure, rather than illuminate, the trade-offs involved in making decisions with multiple objectives.
The discussion above highlights what can be considered a gap in literature to date.
The necessity to identify and apply a quantitative method to position items within the KPM is therefore a pressing need, prior to undertaking subsequent analysis.

The data used for this research comes from a large organization's procurement function whose primary goal is to leverage its enterprise reach in order to capitalize on strategic sourcing opportunities that will maximize value and savings to the organization and stakeholders.
From 2010 to 2014, this organization's procurement function spent nearly $43 Billion in support of its operations.
This figure represents nearly 11% of the total 2010-2014 budget of this organization.

As the organization continues to face ongoing operations in multiple locations, the increased scrutiny by senior leadership to improve strategic sourcing, and the looming threat of an overburdened economy, the need to uncover areas ripe for value maximization and reduced supply chain risk cannot be overstated.

Thus, this research was guided by the desire to apply the KPM strategic sourcing model to this organizational context to allow the enterprise to develop distinctive management approaches for its sourcing activities.

To accomplish this the organization required an objective and quantitative approach to position items within the KPM and identify the products and services offering the highest potential for value maximization while minimizing supply chain risk through strategic sourcing.
Consequently, the methodology employed is for the purpose of positioning items within the matrix and identifying optimal candidates to begin strategic sourcing initiatives.
The KPM is, in essence, a multi-objective decision model.
Kraljic indicates that a trade-off exists between two factors: supply risk and value impact.
The location of a commodity or service within the KPM represents this trade-off.
Kraljic argues that an organization can fully exploit its buying power and achieve greater value gains when supply risk is minimized and value measures are maximized.
This occurs when items fall within the Leverage quadrant of the KPM.

On the other hand, items that fall outside of the Leverage quadrant offer less value impact or increased supply chain risk exposure to the firm and require a different approach, or strategy, for purchasing.

The general idea behind the KPM is to minimize supply vulnerability and maximize value impact while at the same time matching external resources provided by suppliers with the internal needs of the buying firm.

Thus, an assumption is made regarding an overall direction of preference towards the Leverage quadrant since it is in this quadrant that a purchasing organization is most likely to achieve maximum value improvements while minimizing risk exposure.
Relative to the exemplar organization, the objective to minimize supply risk was interpreted as minimizing supply market complexity.

Risk, according to literature, is restricted to situations in which both the set of possibilities and the probability distribution over this set are known whereas decisions under uncertainty are usually made on grounds other than logical calculation.
Kraljic uses the term risk to identify a supply market that is comprised of many factors that affect its complexity rather than outcomes with an associated probability and consequence.
Parnell add that risk neutrality is often seen in Government and non-profit decision making.
Therefore, we narrow our focus to a risk-less model with a fundamental objective to Minimize Supply Market Complexity.
This also serves to simplify the model by eliminating the requirement to incorporate risk attitude.
Furthermore, for the objective to maximize value, the exemplar organization sought to Maximize Strategic Impact.

The ability of an organization to carry out its particular operations and processes is critical to the success of the organizations strategy and the centralized purchasing function of the organization providing the data for this research is pivotal to the strategic success of its various locations.
Thus, for the exemplar organization the fundamental objectives decision-makers were focused on included.
Within the exemplar organization, individual products and services acquired are referred to as Product and Service Codes.
Given the two fundamental objectives and their respective direction of preference, Multi-Objective Decision Analysis is implemented as a framework to quantitatively position PSCs within the KPM.
We recall that the terms minimize and maximize connotes the direction of preference of the decision maker for a particular objective.
In our case, a less complex supply market is preferred over a more com- plex supply market and higher strategic impact is preferred over less strategic impact.
No manipulation of the market or the organization's strategy is required or intended when positioning a PSC.
However, the direction of preference is a requirement when using MODA and is vital to our methodology as will be seen in the following sections.
The alternatives for this research are simply the set of PSCs, or procurement items, that the organization desires to position within the KPM.
Although there are 1702 PSCs involved in contracts, the organization supplied a subset of PSCs for this analysis that accounts for 80% of 2010Ð2014 spend.
Specifically, we seek to position 138 PSCs selected by the organization.
Supply market complexity can be measured by various attributes such as market structure, concentration, risk, and price trends.
To capture these characteristics of a market, organizations can develop internal algorithms to measure and aggregate this information or leverage external approaches.
The World Buyer Power Score is one such external resource.
IBISWorld is a research organization whose reports delve into supply markets for a particular good or service.
The IBISWorld Buyer Power Score is comprised of three components: price trends, market structure, and market risk.
Each consists of factors such as availability of substitutes, market share concentration, and product specialization.
Switching costs are also considered.
These factors are weighted, scored, and aggregated to produce an overall buyer power score, which ranges between 1 and 5 with increments of 0.
A higher score indicates greater buyer strength and a less complex market.
The current organization has used the IBISWorld Buyer Power Score metric for several years to monitor the complexity of its supply market.
The organization obtains IBISWorld reports for each PSC as part of their market research efforts.
Therefore, let X be the IBISWorld Buyer Power Score, which represents our measure of supply market complexity.
A value function for this attribute provides a value score.
A single attribute value function is all that is required since a single attribute was identified to measure this fundamental objective.
Kirkwood identified two possible SAVFs: Piecewise linear and exponential.
To select the appropriate function, interviews were conducted with members of the purchasing function of the organization who are experts in strategic sourcing and have experience using the KPM.
The goal of the interviews was to identify and build a value preference structure for each attribute by eliciting values using the fractile method as explained by Howard and Abbas.
The Resource-based view posits that organizations achieve strategic impact through their resources.
However, it has been recognized that tangible and intangible assets cannot provide competitive advantages by themselves.
Hansen argue that it is not simply the possession of valuable and inimitable resources, but how leadership manages these resources is just as important.
Thus, the ability of a manager to orchestrate its resources is fundamental to executing the organization's strategic objectives and achieving competitive advantage.
Unfortunately, in many large bureaucratic enterprises, government entities, and non-profit organizations, forced budget reductions remove managers  control of resource orchestration.
In fact, peanut butter spread reductions are often made where all units and functions experience a common reduction.
Yet in times of budget increases, managers across the organizational hierarchies are free, to an extent, to exercise judgment in purchasing decisions to align resources with strategic objectives.

Thus, in times of normal or increasing budget activities, managers will direct their spend activities towards those resources they believe will have the largest strategic impact to their specific mission.
In conversations with senior leadership from our exemplar organization, which is a large bureaucratic enterprise, this practice was considered the norm.

Furthermore, in our conversations with senior leadership and management at various levels within the organization, it was commonly discussed that managers applied budget increases first to the organization's most strategically critical goods and services.

Thus, in coordination with management, we leverage this finding to deduce which PSCs were most critical to the organization by identifying those PSCs that experienced the largest post-budget-cut rebound in spend.
To do so, we targeted the change in spend from 2013 to 2014.
Spend data from the organization shows that 2013 included significant budget cuts of approximately 13%.
However, the 2014 budgets for spend increased by nearly 6%.
This trend was visible at the most aggregate levels down to the most disaggregated levels.
Consequently, as 2014 budgets increased, we identified those PSCs that experienced the largest post-budget-cut rebound in spend.
To do so, we calculate the percent change of spend for each PSC from 2013 to 2014.
We also calculate overall organization spend over the same period, compute the deviation between the two, and scaled from 0 to 1.
Therefore, let Y be the delta between the overall organization spend slope and PSC spend slope from 2013 to 2014.
Those PSCs with values closer to one represent spend that aims to maximize strategic impact.
After solving each single attribute value function, we obtain a ordered pair for each PSC.
This ordered pair allows us to plot each PSC on the organization's modified KMP.
The coordinate plane is also divided into 4 equal quadrants.
These partitions divide the coordinate plane into the four quadrants that represent the four quadrants of the KPM.
Last, we identify the weights associated with the two fundamental objectives.

Given that Kraljic identifies a unique relationship between both axes of the matrix, a multilinear function must be created rather than a simple additive value model, which has been the subject of the extant literature.
This allows us to capture the preference structure and relative importance between the two objectives.
This is also critical in helping to understand the relative importance of each measure and its dependency on the difference between the worst and the best value points of each measure.
Furthermore, as will be illustrated, we can perform sensitivity analysis on these swing weights to gain even further robustness in our preference structure trade-space.
Weights associated with each attribute and their interactions are determined following Keeney and Raiffa.
Next, we determine which attribute the organization prefers to swing to its best case while keeping the other attribute at its worst case and elicit its value.
We then determine the value of the opposing situation, swinging the other attribute to its best case while keeping the first attribute at its worst case and elicit this value.
Positioning the PSCs in the KPM illustrates that 137 of the 138 PSCs are positioned in the Leverage quadrant.

Further investigation regarding this phenomenon discovered that the organization's selection of PSCs for analysis was based on a specific set of key performance indicators that identified what the organization considered to be the best opportunity for strategic impact.
The combination of KPI score and annual spend was used to produce the prioritized list of 138 PSCs.
Thus, we should expect to see them in the Leverage quadrant.

Further investigation into this set of PSCs revealed that items procured to run the organization's various locations are more often than not common goods and services of which markets exist beyond the organization's needs.
Thus, we should expect to see a bulk of PSCs congregating to the left and even to the upper left of the matrix.
Moreover, in Kraljic's seminal work, he used an example of a company that positioned 5000 items.
Only 75, or 1.5% were positioned on the right side of the matrix.

However, this initial assessment helped to confirm that the objective quantitative approach applied aligned with the organization's internal analytic processes to identify strategically important PSCs.

Furthermore, that the bulk of the PSCs are in the upper left of the Leverage quadrant, the organization should be able to leverage its buying power to maximize strategic impact while minimizing supply chain risk with these PSCs.
However, the question remains of these PSCs, which should the organization focus on first to maximize strategic impact while minimizing supply chain risk?
One approach to address this concern is to let the cutoff points be produced by the data rather than using the arbitrary 0.50 cutoff value.
The weight associated with the Strategic quadrant represents a scenario where an item is extremely important to the mission but is only found in a very complex market.
The weight associated with the Noncritical item represents an item not important to the mission yet abides in a non-complex, buyer-empowered market.
Either scenario is not preferred by the organization's representatives.
Value preference elicitation sessions revealed they preferred to swing attribute Y to its best while holding attribute X at its worst over the opposing situation.
The value they assigned to this swing was 52%, thus wy = 0.52.
The same held for the opposing situation.
The non-dominated PSCs are marked accordingly with the assumption that the organization prefers to maximize the benefit of those PSCs with the largest cost impact to the organization.
The non-dominated PSCs form the Pareto optimal set, or efficient frontier, of PSCs.
Seven non-dominated PSCs are identified as the Pareto Optimal Set.

When considering value preferences and overall spend, this set of seven represents the optimal set of PSCs for the organization to begin strategy comparisons and implement commercial best practice purchasing strategies.
To assess the robustness of our results we performed sensitivity analysis on the swing weights assigned to each single attribute value function.
Sensitivity analysis allows us to see the impact on the MAVF score when adjusting the weights within a given range and provides feedback regarding biases in the modeling and elicitation procedures.
For every combination of weight adjustments, we consistently identified 12 of the 138 PSCs with the highest MAVF score indicating them as most likely candidates for initial strategy comparisons.
In fact, four PSCs never changed position.
These results strengthen the case that the underlying MODA framework is robust and that we have adequately captured the value preferences for procured goods and services.
Past research supports the argument that multi-attribute utility modeling typically yields valid mathematical representations of the preferences of decision-makers.
Lastly, to further examine our MODA framework, we assessed eleven PSCs that were not part of the organization's originally prioritized set of 138.

However, these two PSCs were not originally prioritized by the organization's internal approach to be considered for strategic sourcing initiatives.

Although we understand the organization's desire to focus its efforts on PSCs that have large impacts on its overall budget, our analysis highlights that these prioritization criteria may result in potential missed opportunities for strategic sourcing.
In fact, this discussion promotes positioning PSCs within the KPM using the MODA-framework as an effective starting point a priori to implementing the organization's usual internal analysis.

This seems to indicate that a buyer's market may not exist.
Therefore, according to our scoring criteria, we assumed this is a complex market in which to operate and the organization confirmed this assumption.
This, along with the fact that spending remained steady from 2010 to 2014, resulted in G002 being positioned in the Strategic quadrant.
Although G002 is only responsible for an average of $3.6M of annual spend for 2010-2014, the KPM appropriately positions it in the Strategic quadrant.

Again, by not considering KPM position first and only relying on the combination of KPI score and overall spend, the organization may not be able to identify PSCs that should require further investigation as a result of its divergence from the Leverage quadrant.
Finally, after calculating the MAVF scores for these non-prioritized PSCs and including them in the Cost-Benefit Trade Space plot, we find that the Pareto Optimal Set does not change.
Again, this is due to the low FY10-14 spend of the non-prioritized PSCs.
We noted that although non-prioritized PSCs may not land in the Pareto Optimal Set, the aggregate spend of non-prioritized PSCs within the Leverage quadrant should not be overlooked.
We emphasize that the Leverage Quadrant is the starting point for finding PSCs with high potential for maximizing value impact while minimizing risk exposure.
The KPM helps identify such PSCs.
The Pareto Optimal set simply identifies which of those PSCs to select first for implementing strategic sourcing efforts.
Strategic purchasing is a critical element of success for today's organization and applying a purchasing portfolio approach has become one of the dominant purchasing strategies.
Moreover, Kraljic's portfolio matrix has become the fundamental structure that most purchasing portfolio strategies rely upon.
However, within the extant literature, positioning products and services within the different quadrants of the KPM is primarily based on subjective judgment of the decision makers.
This has left two important questions unresolved.
How does a purchasing manager quantitatively and objectively position a product or service within the matrix?
Which products and services should the organization focus on first when implementing a strategic sourcing initiative?
The proposed approach helps to address the current gap in the KPM literature regarding the necessity to identify and apply a quantitative method to position items within the KPM.
With limited applications of quantitative techniques to position items within the KPM, our method expands the objective and quantitative rigor that can accompany a KPM application.

Furthermore, our approach goes beyond the quantitative positioning of product and services in the KPM, but also provides a rigorous approach to quantitatively and objectively rank-order products and services for strategic sourcing initiatives.
Specifically, we introduce the use of MODA into the KPM literature base to capture the value preferences of decision makers.
First, we applied a SAVF to objectively quantify the dimensions and attributes of the products and services.
We then leverage swing weights and a MAVF to rank-order the products and services to identify those, which represent the most likely candidates for strategic sourcing opportunities.
A cost-benefit comparison further refined this list by identifying the Pareto optimal set of products and services most conducive to strategic sourcing opportunities.
A sensitivity analysis and validation set assessment was performed to ratify the robustness of our methodology.

Our approach is managerial relevant since it not only improves the objectiveness, quality, and confidence of positioning products and services within the KPM matrix, but it also helps decision makers identify those products and services that are optimal candidates to begin strategic sourcing initiatives.
Due to the ease of implementation, organizations can quickly implement our solution.
Furthermore, by leveraging the swing weights and sensitivity analysis, procurement managers will understand how the solution space changes based on managerial preferences.
This allows managers to identify those products and services that consistently appear optimal for strategic sourcing initiatives regardless of preference structure.

The organization whose data was used for this research acknowledged that the objective and quantitative approach proposed and demonstrated by this research represents a simpler and faster approach than the subjective approaches advocated in the literature.
The leadership also acknowledged that this approach led to higher quality and more insightful results than the approaches they had used in the past.
The management team is excited about the time and effort savings that this new approach represents.
They also view this approach as a way of providing objective continuity across leadership changes and between the various levels of leadership within their organization.
Despite the rigor of our analysis, we accept that certain limitations exist that might entice further research.
First, our analysis leverages a SAVF for each of the attributes assessed.
Future research can expand this approach by incorporating MAVFs so that multiple measures could be used to value a given attribute.
Moreover, future research can strive to incorporate new attributes that potentially contribute to the two dimensions.
Furthermore, our research focuses on quantifying the attributes of procured products and services and indicating where strategic sourcing efforts should focus first.
However, our research does not identify the appropriate procurement strategy techniques that should be applied to these identified opportunities.
Future research should seek to link the results of our quantified approach to specific procurement strategies to provide decision makers with a complete purchasing portfolio framework.
An additional limitation of this analysis is the lack of support for the cutoff values that produce the four KPM quadrants.

Future research should analyze possible cutoff value approaches, whether they are determined from statistical properties of the data such as median, mean, standard deviations, or quantiles, and see how these change the interpretation of the results or perspective.
This may provide significant insight into whether the current arbitrary 0 cutoff is reasonable or if alternative approaches are more appropriate depending on the business context.
Lastly, this analysis relies on the data from a single organization.

Future research should strive to replicate the approach advocated here using data from other organizations to perhaps strengthen the overall generalizability of the approach, to verify whether or not the assumptions made hold true in other contexts, and to determine whether or not the cutoff values utilized are equally applicable to other organizations.
Many organizations only leverage a fraction of what could potentially be managed and saved through strategic sourcing.
Strategic sourcing even one additional percent of the spend of large organizations could equate to billions of dollars of value improvement.

Implementing strategic sourcing via a purchasing portfolio framework, organizations have the opportunity to more aggressively leverage their buying power and select appropriate sourcing strategies and tactics.

With Kraljic's portfolio matrix being the most widely used diagnostic and prescriptive purchasing portfolio framework, this research greatly contributes to this framework by providing a more quantitative and rigorously grounded matrix.
This provides purchasing managers an objective, quantitative approach to identify products and services ripe for strategic sourcing initiatives.
